title: Magnolia to give London listings some sparkle

Sat, Jul 11, 2015, 20:49 BST - UK Markets closed Magnolia to give London listings some sparkle By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 1 hour 48 minutes ago +0.062 
Silver jewellery business to launch £30m flotation on London's junior market next month 
London's junior market will be given some sparkle when silver jeweller Magnolia launches a stock market listing next month. 
The company, which sells handcrafted bracelets, rings and necklaces from kiosks across the UK’s busiest shopping centres, is expected to be valued at up to £30m when it launches on Aim. 
Magnolia is looking to raise around £5m to fund the launch of an ecommerce site and accelerate an international expansion plan using its franchise business. 
Magnolia has 150 stores across five countries including Israel, Canada, Portugal, Australia and the UK. Each kiosk stocks around 2,000 items made from sterling silver. 
The company, which targets the affordable luxury market, competes with expanding rivals Danish firm Pandora (Copenhagen: PNDORA.CO - news ) and Germany’s Thomas Sabo. 
The Tel Aviv-based company will join a growing list of Israeli enterprises floating on London’s markets including digital advertising firms Matomy Media and Marimedia (LSE: MARI.L - news ) and trading site Plus500 (Stuttgart: P55.SG - news ) . 
The company is currently owned by Israeli private equity firm Markstone, which last year was forced to tap investors for an additional $81m (£50m) to survive. Markstone used the cash call to pay off the debts in its other portfolio companies in order to keep Magnolia in its hands. 
Magnolia has kiosks in busy shopping centres 
A spokesman said that Markstone was not using the listing process to cash out and the new money raised would be used to grow the company. The private equity firm will also be prevented from selling shares for at least a year after listing. 
Magnolia is being advised by boutique firm Spark Advisory Partners while Daniel Stewart is its broker. 
The jeweller reported sales of $57m (£36m) last year, gross profits of $36m and $5m in adjusted earnings
